piece.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: an amount of something that has been separated from the main part
piece.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: She cut the cake into four equal pieces.
Chop the potato into bite-sized pieces.
He broke off a piece of bread and gave it her.
Cut off a piece of wood 5 cm in length.
His trousers were held up with a piece of string.
Would you like a small or a large piece?
piece.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: one of the parts that something divides or breaks into
piece.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: His father had taught him how to take a gun to pieces.
The shelving comes to pieces (=divides into separate parts) for easy transport.
The shower head just came to pieces (=broke into separate parts) in my hand.
The fireplace was carefully dismantled piece by piece (=one part at a time).
The china dish lay in pieces on the floor.
Individual pieces of text can be cut and pasted to their correct position.
piece.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a single thing of a particular type, or something that is one of several similar things
piece.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: a three-piece suite (=two chairs and a sofa)
Pass me another piece of paper.
You should eat three pieces of fruit a day.
She was wearing a single piece of jewellery.
You need to examine every piece of evidence first.
piece.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a small amount of something that is interesting, useful, or unusual in some way
piece.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Let me give you a piece of advice.
We’re witnessing a piece of history in the making.
It really was an extraordinary piece of luck.
piece.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: a dispute about a piece of land
piece.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: something that has been produced by an artist, musician, or writer
piece.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: The LSO will perform a much-loved concert piece.
piece.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: a short article in a newspaper or magazine or part of a television or radio programme that is about a particular subject
piece.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Did you read that piece in ‘The Observer’ about censorship?
Robert wrote a short piece on the earthquake.
piece.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: a coin of a particular value
piece.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Have you change for a 50-cent piece?
piece.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: Robert slipped two gold pieces into the man’s hand.
piece.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: a small object used in a game such as chess
piece.translation[0].note_box[0].section: an amount of something that has been cut or separated from the main part
Could I have another piece of cake?
Emma cut the pie into eight pieces.
a piece. Bit is more informal than piece and is often used about smaller pieces
The notes were written on bits of paper.
He threw a bit of wood onto the fire.
a small piece of something solid or firm that does not have a regular shape
a small piece of paper, cloth etc that is no longer needed
I wrote the phone number on a scrap of paper.
The dog was eating scraps of food off the floor.
a long narrow piece of cloth, paper etc
The leather had been cut into strips.
a thin flat piece of something such as paper, glass, or metal
a thin flat piece of bread, cake, meat etc cut from a larger piece
Cut the tomatoes into thin slices.
a piece of something solid that does not have a regular shape – used especially about food, rock, or metal
The fruit was cut into large chunks.
a large piece with rough edges, which has been cut or has broken off a bigger piece of food, rock etc
a piece of something solid, which has straight sides
a thick flat piece of stone, or of cake, meat etc
The floor had been made from stone slabs.
a piece that has six square sides – used especially about food
a piece that has a thick end and a pointed end, and is shaped like a triangle – used especially about food and metal
a block of soap, chocolate, candy, or metal, which has straight sides
gold bars worth more than £26 million
I usually have two rashers of bacon for breakfast.
a small piece that has broken off something, especially something hard
The window shattered, covering them with fragments of glass.
a very small piece of bread, cake etc
There were just a few crumbs left on the plate.
a piece of something such as dirt or dust which is so small you almost cannot see it
She brushed the specks of dust from the table.
a very small amount of a liquid
There were drops of blood on the floor.
I felt a drop of rain.
piece.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a coin of a particular value
piece.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Does anyone have change for a 50 pence piece?
piece.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: a single thing of a particular type
piece.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: to supply or sell something as a single thing rather than in a pair or a set
piece.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: if people work or are paid by the piece, they are paid for each thing they produce, not for the amount of time it takes to produce it
